Courses.Name: ENGLISH 0005W - ENGLISH FOR ACADEMIC PURPOSES
Description: Combines communication skills through a cross-curricular approach. Students explore complex content from a range of subject areas to gain the foundation required to purposefully read in order to present information and formulate written arguments. Students engage in critical and analytical thinking through readings, and develop listening strategies through class discussions.
Extra Information: 8 class/lecture hours, 2 tutorial hours.

Notes: REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Registration in a Preliminary Year program at Brescia University College.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Registration in a Preliminary Year program at Brescia University College.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 0005X - ENGLISH FOR ACADEMIC PURPOSES
Description: Combines communication skills through a cross-curricular approach. Students explore complex content from a range of subject areas to gain the foundation required to purposefully read in order to present information and formulate written arguments. Students engage in critical and analytical thinking through readings, and develop listening strategies through class discussions.
Extra Information: 8 class/lecture hours, 2 tutorial hours.

Notes: REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Registration in a Preliminary Year program at Brescia University College.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Registration in a Preliminary Year program at Brescia University College.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 0011A - POETRY AND DRAMA
Description: This course is designed to introduce the student to the study of literature with a focus on poetry and drama, and may include examples from film. The course will encourage a critical approach to literature, with special attention to essay-writing skills.

Notes: ONLINE SYNCHRONOUS.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Registration in a Preliminary Year program at Brescia University College.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 0012B - SHORT STORIES AND NOVELS
Description: This course is designed to introduce the student to the study of literature with a focus on short stories and novels. The course will encourage a critical approach to literature, with special attention to essay-writing skills.

Notes: ONLINE SYNCHRONOUS.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Registration in a Preliminary Year program at Brescia University College.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 1020E - UNDERSTANDING LITERATURE TODAY
Description: By studying a broad range of exciting and important literary works from the past and present, this course will increase your understanding and appreciation not just of the richness and power of the works themselves, but also of the role of literature in reflecting and shaping our perceptions of the world and of ourselves.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Grade 12U English or permission of the Department. For part time students who have been admitted without the OSSD, this permission will be granted as a matter of course.
RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Grade 12U English or permission of the Department. For part time students who have been admitted without the OSSD, this permission will be granted as a matter of course.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 1022E - ENRICHED INTRO TO ENGLISH LIT
Description: This course provides an enriched survey of the major genres, historical periods, and critical approaches to English for students with a particular interest in literature and culture. In lecture and small group tutorials, you will study poetry, prose, and drama with special emphasis on developing superior analytical and writing skills.

Notes: REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): 85% or better in Grade 12U English or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 1024E - FORMS OF FICTION
Description: An introduction to the study of a selection of fiction ranging from the Greek epic to the modern novel, including both short and longer forms; and a variety of fictional modes and narrative techniques. Major authors studied include Homer, Swift, Austen, Dickens, Dostoevsky, and Virginia Woolf.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Grade 12U English or permission of the Department. For part time students who have been admitted without the OSSD, this permission will be granted as a matter of course.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 1027F - STORYTELLER'S ART I:INTRO TO N
Description: Storytelling defines who we are and our relation to the community, the nation, and the world. This course explores the rich and diverse traditions of storytelling: such as, oral tales, short stories, classic fiction, and graphic novels. Instruction by lecture and tutorials; emphasis on developing strong analytical and writing skills.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Grade 12U English or permission of the Department. For part time students who have been admitted without the OSSD, this permission will be granted as a matter of course.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 1028G - STORYTELLER'S ART II:TOPICS IN
Description: This course explores a particular theme, mode, or genre of storytelling. Consult the Department of English for details of current course offerings. Instruction is by lecture and tutorials; emphasis on developing strong analytical and writing skills.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Grade 12U English or permission of the Department. For part time students who have been admitted without the OSSD, this permission will be granted as a matter of course.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 1042E - LITERATURE & CULTURAL REP
Description: Combining the study of classic literature with works of current cultural importance, such as graphic novels and film, this course explores how our world and our lives are formed and informed by the stories we tell.

Notes: PRIORITY TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT HURON. JULY 28 PRIORITY CHANGE: ACCESS TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Grade 12U English or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT HURON. JULY 28 PRIORITY CHANGE: ACCESS TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Grade 12U English or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 1901E - FOUNDATIONS IN WTC
Description: The English Literature unit of the King's Foundations in Western Thought and

Civilization is supplemented by the study of art and music. It investigates influential works of literature from ancient to modern times through an interdisciplinary perspective, with special focus on innovations in literary form and cultural contexts.
Extra Information: 3 hours. There may be additional costs associated with field trips.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO KING'S FOUNDATIONS IN WESTERN THOUGHT AND CIVILIZATION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Must be registered in the King's Foundations in Western Thought and Civilization, or the former Foundations in the Humanities.
Corequisite(s): History 1901E and Philosophy 1901E.
RESTRICTED TO KING'S FOUNDATIONS IN WESTERN THOUGHT AND CIVILIZATION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): Must be registered in the King's Foundations in Western Thought and Civilization, or the former Foundations in the Humanities.
Corequisite(s): History 1901E and Philosophy 1901E.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2018A - THE CULTURE OF LEADERSHIP
Description: This course addresses the complex nature of leadership represented in key works of literature and culture, from Malory to Alice Munro, Shakespeare to David Mamet. We will focus on the ethical dilemmas and moral choices faced by leaders to ask what role a leader plays: hero, manager, thinker, strategist, artist, figurehead, authority?

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2023B - JRR TOLKIEN CS LEWIS & FRIENDS
Description: This course explores the fiction of J.R.R. Tolkien (The Lord of the Rings), C.S. Lewis (The Chronicles of Narnia), and their circle in relation to the western literary tradition; genres such as fantasy, science fiction, and detective fiction; and the twentieth-century historical context.

Notes: ONLINE-SYNCHRONOUS. MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
ONLINE-SYNCHRONOUS. MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2027F - LITERATURE AND FILM
Description: Selected works of literature and film representing a variety of genres and historical-cultural periods are studied to consider how film- makers have adapted literary works into cinema.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2033E - CHILDREN'S LITERATURE
Description: Readings from significant books written for children, selected primarily for literary quality. Some attention will be given to the historic evolution of "Children's Literature" as a separate class, but the principal aim of the course will be to consider the nature and development of the two major genres: nonsense verse and romance.

Notes: ONLINE-SYNCHRONOUS.  RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
ONLINE COURSE. NOT OPEN TO STUDENTS AT KING'S. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2041F - SPECIAL TOPICS IN DRAMA
Description: In this course, students participating in a major Western theatre production explore in theory and practice approaches to text in performance. Only students working as an actor, director, stage manager, assistant stage manager, lighting, set or costume designer may enrol. Permission of the Chair of Undergraduate Studies required to enrol.
Antirequisite(s): English 2041F/G if taken prior to September 2014.

Notes: ONLY STUDENTS WORKING AS AN ACTOR, DIRECTOR, STAGE MANAGER, ASSISTANT STAGE MANAGER, LIGHTING, SET OR COSTUME DESIGNER IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH FALL DRAMA PRODUCTION MAY ENROL. REGISTRATION THROUGH THE DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH. FALL DRAMA PRODUCTION: TBA

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2071F - SPECULATV FICTN: SCIENCE FICTN
Description: From Mary Shelley's Frankenstein to Ridley Scott's Blade Runner, a consideration of the history and development of science fiction. Will include science fiction themes such as the Other, new technologies, chaos theory, cybernetics, paradoxes of space/time travel, first contact, and alien worlds.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
ONLINE COURSE. NOT OPEN TO STUDENTS AT KING'S. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2071G - SPECULATV FICTN: SCIENCE FICTN
Description: From Mary Shelley's Frankenstein to Ridley Scott's Blade Runner, a consideration of the history and development of science fiction. Will include science fiction themes such as the Other, new technologies, chaos theory, cybernetics, paradoxes of space/time travel, first contact, and alien worlds.

Notes: ONLINE COURSE. NOT OPEN TO STUDENTS AT KING'S. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2072F - SPECULATIVE FICTION: FANTASY
Description: A study of the purposes and historical origins of fantasy, and modern developments in fantasy: alternate worlds, horror or ghost stories, sword & sorcery, heroic fantasy. May include writers such as Tolkien, Simmons, Peake, Herbert, Beagle, Rowling.

Notes: ONLINE COURSE. NOT OPEN TO STUDENTS AT KING'S. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2072G - SPECULATIVE FICTION: FANTASY
Description: A study of the purposes and historical origins of fantasy, and modern developments in fantasy: alternate worlds, horror or ghost stories, sword & sorcery, heroic fantasy. May include writers such as Tolkien, Simmons, Peake, Herbert, Beagle, Rowling.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

NOT OPEN TO STUDENTS AT KING'S. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2076F - MEDIEVAL HEROES
Description: Many medieval heroes and villains are alive today: Thor, Loki, Beowulf, Joan of Arc, Richard the Lionheart, Eleanor of Aquitaine, Robin Hood, Arthur, Mordred, Hildegard of Bingen, Sylvester II. This course will investigate these real-life and literary figures, considering their construction in medieval texts, and their reconstruction through the ages.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2091G - SPECIAL TOPICS
Description: Please consult the Department for current offerings.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. TOPIC: PANDEMIC!: NARRATIVES OF CONTAGION AND DISEASE.
RESTRICTED TO YEAR 2, 3, AND 4 STUDENTS. TOPIC: FROM PIXELS TO PAPYRUS: A BRIEF HISTORY OF THE THINGS WE READ.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2092F - SPECIAL TOPICS IN POPULAR LIT.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2099G - MUNRO CHAIR IN CREATIVITY
Description: This course, led by the Alice Munro Chair in Creativity, will allow students to explore creativity and its role in the production and study of literature in English and the Arts and Humanities more broadly. See the Department Website for the specific focus of this year’s course.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO YEAR 2, 3, AND 4 STUDENTS. CROSS-LISTED WITH ARTHUM 3393G. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2200F - HISTORY OF THEORY & CRITICISM
Description: An introduction to important issues in the history of literary criticism and theory from Plato to the twentieth century.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2201G - CONTEMP. THEORY AND CRITICISM
Description: This course builds on the historical foundations of English 2200F/G to concentrate on important issues in contemporary literary theory and criticism. English 2200F/G is recommended as preparation for English 2201F/G.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2202G - STUDIES IN POETICS
Description: An introduction to important issues and concepts in the theory and analysis of poetry from different periods.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2203G - STUDIES IN NARRATIVE THEORY
Description: An introduction to important issues and concepts in the theory and analysis of narrative from different periods.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2265G - INTRODUCTION TO THEORY
Description: Introduction to the major modes of literary and cultural theory, and the prevailing issues within them pertaining to medium and form, gender and sexuality, race and nation, culture and history.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2299F - CRITICAL PRACTICE
Description: This course offers an intensive examination of the major critical methodologies relevant to the academic study of literature. In weekly two-hour lectures and weekly one-hour tutorials that encourage the critical practice of slow reading, students will examine one or more primary literary texts and consider it through a variety of critical lenses.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or Writing 1020F/G or Writing 2101F/G or permission of the Department.
WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2301E - BRITISH LITERATURE SURVEY
Description: This course investigates the changing forms of literature produced in the British Isles from the Middle Ages to the present. It addresses key movements and styles through careful analysis of both major authors, such as Shakespeare, Austen, Woolf, or Yeats, and some less well-known yet engaging figures.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. CROSS-LISTED WITH ENGLISH 2399E 530.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2325F - VICTORIAN LITERATURE
Description: A reading of works of poetry, fiction, and prose by representative men and women writers. The course examines continuities with the previous age as well as innovations in literary forms and subjects.
Antirequisite(s): English 2324E and the former English 3444E.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2335G - BRIT LIT-1945+:MAJ AUTHRS
Description: An introduction to poets such as Larkin, Hughes, Heaney, and Boland, and novelists such as Fowles, Lessing, Murdoch, and Ackroyd. Discussion will relate the works to social, cultural and political developments in the U.K. from the post-war period to the present.
Antirequisite(s): English 2334E and the former English 3554E.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2337G - JRR TOLKIEN CS LEWIS & FRIENDS
Description: This course explores the fiction of J.R.R. Tolkien (The Lord of the Rings), C.S. Lewis (The Chronicles of Narnia), and their circle in relation to the western literary tradition; genres such as fantasy, science fiction, and detective fiction; and the twentieth-century historical context.

Notes: ONLINE-SYNCHRONOUS. MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020E; or both English 1027F/G and English 1028F/G; or English 1022E or English 1024E or English 1035E or English 1036E or English 1901E, or permission of the department.
ONLINE-SYNCHRONOUS. MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020E; or both English 1027F/G and English 1028F/G; or English 1022E or English 1024E or English 1035E or English 1036E or English 1901E, or permission of the department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2356G - TOP IN 20C CAN LIT IN ENG
Description: This course offers an in-depth study of an author, theme, movement or literary form during the period.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. TOPIC: INDIGENOUS WOMEN’S RESILIENCE: NOT JUST MISSING AND MURDERED.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. TOPIC: INDIGENOUS WOMEN’S RESILIENCE: NOT JUST MISSING AND MURDERED.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2372F - SHAKESPEARE
Description: A close study of at least six plays by Shakespeare representing the three main types: history, comedy, and tragedy.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2399E - BRIT LIT SURVEY: CREATIVITY
Description: This course investigates the development of British literature from the Middle Ages to the present. It addresses key movements and styles through analysis of major authors, such as Shakespeare, Austen, and Yeats. Student work includes some creative writing elements that engage with the technical and thematic concerns of the course.
Antirequisite(s): English 2301E and the former English 2307E.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. CROSS-LISTED WITH ENGLISH 2301E 530.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 English courses from 1020-1999, or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. CROSS-LISTED WITH ENGLISH 2301E 530.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 English courses from 1020-1999, or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2401E - AMERICAN LITERATURE SURVEY
Description: This course offers a survey of important texts and authors from the Puritan and Revolutionary periods to the present. It addresses not only the major movements and styles of American literature associated with such authors as Poe, Dickinson, Twain, Hemingway, and Morrison, but also the innovative work of less familiar Indigenous and ethnic authors.
Antirequisite(s): English 2341E, English 2342F/G, English 2343F/G, English 2344E, English 2345F/G, English 2346F/G and English 3664E, or the former English 2308E.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2501E - CANADIAN LITERATURE SURVEY
Description: What does literature tell us about the making of a nation and its citizens? Spanning the period from imperial exploration to Confederation to the present day, this course examines Canada’s vibrant literary culture. Students will encounter a diverse range of genres and authors, from accounts of early explorers to current internationally acclaimed and award-winning writers.
Antirequisite(s): English 2354E, English 2356F/G and English 3774E, or the former English 2309E.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2551G - SP TPCS IN ENG & CULTR STUDIES
Description: Please consult the department for current offerings.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. TOPIC: CLIMATE CHANGE AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE IN WORLD LITERATURE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. TOPIC: CLIMATE CHANGE AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE IN WORLD LITERATURE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2601E - GLOBAL LIT. IN ENGLISH SURVEY
Description: This course offers students a great opportunity to survey of the links between and among  different literary traditions and innovations across such diverse geographic regions as Asia, Africa, Australia, South America, and the Caribbean. Through close reading of literary texts written in English, students will explore how cultures produce different--often competing--ways of making meaning.
Antirequisite(s): English 2101, English 2361E, English 2362F/G, English 2363F/G and English 3884E, or the former English 2310E.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2695E - BACKGROUNDS & FOUNDATIONS
Description: An introduction to background texts that are essential to an understanding of current textual practices in English.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 2824G - SPECIAL TOPICS CULTURAL STUDIE
Description: Please consult the department for current offerings.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. TOPIC: AMERICAN DREAMS, AMERICAN NIGHTMARES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. TOPIC: AMERICAN DREAMS, AMERICAN NIGHTMARES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3168E - 19TH CENT LIT: CREATIVITY
Description: This course explores how Romantic and Victorian novelists, poets, essayists, and dramatists consider issues such as nature and imagination, science and rationalism, gender and sexuality, nation and empire, industry and work, prophecy and vision.
Antirequisite:, English 2322F/G, English 2323F/G, English 2324E, English 2325F/G, English 2326F/G, English 3368E and the former English 2321E , the former English 3444E.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. CROSS-LISTED WITH ENGLISH 3368E 530.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 English courses from 1020-1999, or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. CROSS-LISTED WITH ENGLISH 3368E 530.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 English courses from 1020-1999, or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3200G - FEMINIST LITERARY THEORY
Description: An introduction to critical debates in twentieth-century feminist literary theory. Students will study (1) the diversity of feminist approaches to literature, literary production, the politics of language, questions of genre and subjectivity; and (2) the intersections among feminist literary theories, postcolonialism, Marxism, anti-racist criticism, queer theory, and post-structuralism.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3204G - CRITICAL RACE THEORY
Description: This course explores key concepts in critical race theory, focusing on: cultural constructions of race and their connection to settler colonialism and imperialism; the links between race, class, gender, and sexuality; processes of racialization; whiteness as an “invisible” category; the hypervisibility of racialized subjects; and anti-racist cultural production.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. CROSS-LISTED WITH GSWS 3324G AND ARTHUM 3390G. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3265F - ADVANCED THEORY
Description: An advanced study of important topics in one or more mode of literary and cultural theory.
Extra Information: English 2265F/G (Introduction to Theory) is strongly recommended as preparation for this course.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3300 - HISTORY OF ENGLISH LANGUAGE
Description: A study of the historical development of English phonology, morphology, orthography and syntax from Old English to the modern period. At the same time, we examine the changing roles of English (commercial, literary, and administrative) and the different varieties of the language available to its many speakers.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3310 - OLD ENGLISH LANG. AND LIT.
Description: Studying the language and literature of England a millennium ago, we will move from introducing the language to simple prose texts to the poetry of the Exeter and Vercelli Books, and for most of the second term to the study of Beowulf.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or 1.0 of Medieval Studies 1000-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or 1.0 of Medieval Studies 1000-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3316E - LOVE IN THE MIDDLE AGES
Description: This course explores representations of love and desire in the culture of Europe from the twelfth to the fifteenth centuries. While introducing the Middle English language, we will read romances, dream visions, mystical visions, love letters, and plays in their scientific, historical, and religious contexts.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or 1.0 of Medieval Studies 1000-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or 1.0 of Medieval Studies 1000-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3321F - PARADISE LOST
Description: This half-course will examine such topics as Milton’s grand style, Satan, epic heroism (is Paradise Lost an epic or anti-epic?), the nature of innocence, what it means to “fall,” and whether there can be a “fortunate fall.” Attention will also be paid to seventeenth-century politics, science and astronomy.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3328E - RENAISSANCE LITERATURE
Description: Poetry and prose from the renaissance/early modern period, covering a range of male and female authors, such as More, Sidney, Spenser, Marlowe, Shakespeare, Lanyer, Donne, Jonson, Wroth, Herbert, Herrick, Marvell, and Milton; examination of their individual achievements will be combined with studies of form and genre, and the surrounding historical context.
Antirequisite(s): English 2302F/G, English 2303F/G, English 2305F/G, English 2306F/G, and the former English 3224E.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3330E - SHAKESPEARE
Description: Shakespeare remains one of the most influential of English writers. This course studies twelve plays across a range of genres. Instructors may integrate theatre-oriented exercises and/or other dramatic or non-dramatic material, depending on individual emphasis. When possible, the teaching program will include an autumn theatre trip.
Antirequisite(s): English 2371E, English 2372F/G, English 2373F/G, English 2430E and the former English 3227E.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3331G - ADAPTING SHAKESPEARE
Description: Shakespeare invented few of the plots of his plays; instead he used others’ writing. Later artists (including stage and film directors, playwrights, and novelists) have likewise drawn on Shakespeare's plays as inspiration. This half-course explores this range of “Shakespearean adaptation” through close study of two or three major plays.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3333E - EXPERIENTIAL ENGMNT LIT&CULTR
Description: An event-based course where students disseminate their ideas in a public forum. Possible examples may include: an undergraduate conference, a dramatic performance, a communitybased roundtable, an interactive website.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3341F - LIBERTINISM IN 18TH CENT BRIT
Description: The restoration of the monarchy in 1660 ushered in a new and sometimes frightening era of philosophical, social, and sexual freedom. This course explores Libertinism, a subversive doctrine that challenged cultural and sexual norms, through the poems, plays, and prose of the late 17th and early 18th centuries.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3348G - TOPICS IN REST & 18TH-C LIT
Description: This course will be broad enough to provide an introduction to this historical period. However, it may concentrate on a shorter historical span, a particular genre, or use some other principle of selection. Consult the Department for offerings.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. TOPIC: SENTIMENTALISM AND THE EIGHTEENTH-CENTURY NOVEL. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3351F - ROMANTIC REVOLUTIONS
Description: Revolt, radicalism, counter-revolution, reaction, reformation; hope, crisis, peace, war, invention, imagination, catastrophe, wonder, terror. What shadows did revolution cast upon the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries? This course examines a range of texts that reflect Romantic and post-Romantic transformations, upheavals, and reversals in aesthetic, socio-political, scientific, and/or psychological thought and writing.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3361F - SHERLOCK HOLMES
Description: This course studies the detective figure in nineteenth-century literature and culture. Possible topics include: the science of deduction; evidence and forensic practices; panopticism and the society of surveillance; the role of the detective in policing boundaries or race, class, and gender. May also include later film and tv adaptations.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3366F - JANE AUSTEN
Description: Jane Austen is the most important novelist of the Regency period and arguably one of the most important English novelists of any period. This course will examine Austen’s six novels in light of the contemporary issues that informed them and various critical approaches that illuminate them.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): English 1020E, or both English 1027F/G and English 1028F/G, or English 1022E or English 1024E or English 1035E or English 1036E or English 1901E. At least a 70% overall average in English courses. Or by permission of the department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3368E - NINETEENTH CENTURY LITERATURE
Description: From revolution to evolution, this course explores how Romantic and Victorian literature shaped the modern world. Through the study of major novelists, poets, essayists, and dramatists, we will consider issues such as nature and imagination, science and rationalism, gender and sexuality, nation and empire, industry and work, prophecy and vision.
Antirequisite(s): English 2322F/G, English 2323F/G, English 2324E, English 2325F/G, English 2326F/G and the former English 3444E.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. CROSS-LISTED WITH ENGLISH 3168E 530.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or permission of the Department.
MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. CROSS-LISTED WITH ENGLISH 3168E 530.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3378G - TOPICS IN 20TH-CENT. BRIT. LIT
Description: This course will be broad enough to provide an introduction to this historical period. However, it may concentrate on a shorter historical span, a particular genre, or use some other principle of selection. Consult the Department for offerings.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. TOPIC: FORAYS IN FICTION OF THE 20TH AND 21ST CENTURY.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. TOPIC: FORAYS IN FICTION OF THE 20TH AND 21ST CENTURY.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3480F - READING AMERICA NOW
Description: How does the American literary imagination engage contemporary issues? This course approaches recent American fiction and poetry to explore national identity, sexual and racial difference, social and economic injustice, and the significance of media technology. Readings may be accompanied by studies of contemporary visual culture and music.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. CROSS-LISTED WITH ARTHUM 3392F.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3579F - TOPICS IN CANADIAN LITERATURE
Description: This course will explore a narrow topic within post-confederation Canadian literature. It may concentrate on a shorter historical span, a particular genre, or use some other principle of selection. Consult the Department for offerings.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. TOPIC: BLACK WRITING IN CANADA.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. TOPIC: BLACK WRITING IN CANADA.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3680F - INDIGENOUS LIT. TURTLE ISLAND
Description: This course will introduce students to a diverse range of Indigenous storytelling practices from Turtle Island (North America), which may include oral narratives, literature, and visual and performance arts. Students will consider how these practices both shape and are shaped by specific historical and geographical contexts.
Antirequisite(s): Indigenous Studies 3880F/G, the former English 3880F/G.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. CROSS-LISTED WITH INDIGENOUS STUDIES 3880F.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or Indigenous Studies 1020E or permission of the Department.

PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. CROSS-LISTED WITH INDIGENOUS STUDIES 3880F.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or Indigenous Studies 1020E or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3701G - BIBLICAL WOMEN
Description: This course considers biblical women as they are reinterpreted in poetry, novels, short stories and art. When biblical stories are compared with creative interpretations of them, ancient stories are illuminated and contemporary concerns addressed, challenging us to ask new questions of biblical texts and of ourselves as well.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. CROSS-LISTED WITH RELSTUD 2254G.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020E or English 1022E or English 1024E or English 1035E or English 1036E or both English 1027F/G and English 1028F/G, or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3702E - CONSUMING WOMEN
Description: This course examines the construction of women as both consumers and as objects of exchange in British literature from the nineteenth century on. We will study a range of literary texts including prose fiction and non-fiction, drama, and poetry as well as some cultural documents like fashion columns and advertisements.

Notes: ONLINE COURSE. RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3771E - GENRES/FORMS/MODES
Description: An examination of how the genre and modes of expression of various forms, such as novels, drama, film, graphic texts and digital genres influence interpretation and cultural meaning.

Notes: PRIORITY TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT HURON. MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.
PRIORITY TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT HURON. MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020-1999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3775E - TOPICS IN CANADIAN LITERATURE
Description: This course will be broad enough to provide an introduction to this national literature, but narrower in focus than English 3774E. It may concentrate on a shorter historical span, a particular genre, or use some other principle of selection. Consult the Department for offerings.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. TOPIC: SOUTHERN I ONTARIO I GOTHIC. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3891G - TOPICS IN CULTURAL STUDIES
Description: This course offers an advanced study in a more narrowly defined area of cultural studies. Specific content will vary from year to year depending on the instructor. Consult the Department for offerings.

Notes: PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. TOPIC: CULTURAL STUDIES, REPRESENTATION AND IDENTITY.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020E or English 1022E or English 1024E or English 1035E or English 1036E or both English 1027F/G and English 1028F/G, or permission of the Department.

PRIORITY TO ALL ENGLISH MODULES, CERTIFICATE IN THEATRE STUDIES, MAJOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, MINOR IN THEATRE STUDIES, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS, AND SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. TOPIC: CULTURAL STUDIES, REPRESENTATION AND IDENTITY.

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1020E or English 1022E or English 1024E or English 1035E or English 1036E or both English 1027F/G and English 1028F/G, or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3995G - SEMINAR IN LIT AND CREATIVITY
Description: Topics will vary from year to year. Please consult Department for current offerings.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS REGISTERED AT AN AFFILIATED UNIVERSITY COLLEGE.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 3999G - CREATIVE WRITING
Description: An opportunity for students to learn about the craft of fiction and poetry, and to develop their individual voices as they express themselves through a variety of genres. Students should expect to produce a substantial quantity of work. Enrolment limited.

Notes: MAIN CAMPUS STUDENTS REQUIRE HOME FACULTY PERMISSION. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): At least 60% in 1.0 of English 1000-1999, or Writing 1020F/G or Writing 2101F/G or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 4320F - SEM. IN RENAISSANCE LITERATURE

REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): 1.0 from English 3000-3999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 4899F - MUNRO CH. IN CREATIVITY SEM.
Description: A workshop course directed by the Alice Munro Chair in Creativity. The course is aimed at students interested in developing a sustained creative work, whether an early draft of a prose narrative, story collection or poetry. See the Department Website for the specific focus of this year’s seminar.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO ALL YR 4 STUDENTS IN AN ENGLISH & WRITING PROGRAM MAINTAINING A 70% CUMULATIVE AVERAGE, ARTS AND HUMANITIES SPECIAL STUDENTS AND YRS 3 & 4 SCHOLAR'S ELECTIVES. WAIT LIST OPTION AVAILABLE.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): 1.0 from English 3000-3999 or permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: ENGLISH 4999E - THESIS
Description: Individual instruction in selection of a topic, preparation of materials, and writing of a thesis. To take this course, students must apply to the Chair of Undergraduate Studies, Department of English. Restricted to students in fourth year of an English program who have at least an 80% average.

Notes: RESTRICTED TO ALL YR 4 STUDENTS IN AN ENGLISH & WRITING HONORS PROGRAM WHO HAVE AT LEAST AN 80% AVERAGE AND PERMISSION OF THE DEPARTMENT.
REQUISITES: Prerequisite(s): 1.0 from English 3000-3999 or permission of the Department.
